title-group.article-title: Effect of Narrative Reports about Vaccine Adverse Events and Bias-Awareness Disclaimers on Vaccine Decisions
title-group.subtitle: A Simulation of an Online Patient Social Network

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Decision Aids and Risk Perception

abstract.p: Background. As the number of individuals who search for health information in interactive online environments is increasing, patient networks deserve more scientific attention. Objective. To quantitatively examine if and how reading statistical and/or narrative information as typically displayed in patient networks (e.g., patientslikeme.com) affects decisions for pharmaceuticals. Previous work suggests that narrative information (e.g., about vaccine adverse events, VAE) affects risk perceptions and intentions. The authors compare the effect of narrative and statistical information about VAE on vaccination decisions and examine if a disclaimer reduces the narrative bias as well as if low numeracy leads to increased use of the narratives. Method and Design. In an online experiment, 458 participants were randomly assigned to a 3 (relative frequency of vaccine adverse events in 1, 7, or 17 of 20 cases) × 3 (type of information: narratives, summary statistics, or both) × 2 (bias awareness v. control disclaimer) between-subjects design. Measurements. Perceived risk, vaccination intention, and subjective numeracy. Results. A higher relative frequency of cases reporting VAE decreased the intention to get vaccinated. This relation was mediated by increased risk perception. The type of information moderated the contents’ impact: Summary statistics had the smallest impact, whereas narrative information was more influential, and the presence of both types of information had the greatest impact on risk perception. Individuals who received the bias-awareness disclaimer were less influenced by the patient network. Highly numerate individuals were generally more sensitive to the provided information independent of its format. Conclusions. Patient networks can influence vaccination decisions by delivering risk-related information. Disclaimers may help to reduce the influence if desired.

body.p: A growing number of people use the Internet to obtain health information,1–3 such as about pharmaceuticals and their potential side effects (e.g., following vaccinations4,5). Websites that allow and promote interaction among users represent a source of health information that is increasing in popularity. Users of such so-called Web 2.0 applications (e.g., social media), although still in the minority, represent a growing proportion of online communicators. Social patient networks (e.g., www.patientslikeme.com [PLM]) provide individuals the opportunity to locate patients with the same ailment, in order “to share their experience using patient-reported outcomes, find other patients like them matched on demographic and clinical characteristics, and learn from the aggregated data reports of others to improve their outcomes.”6 Furthermore, for individuals interested in desired and undesired effects of pharmaceuticals (e.g., off-label prescription, adverse events7), these networks may provide easily accessible sources of personal experiences.

In such networks, patients can report, rate, and describe their experiences (e.g., vaccine adverse events [VAEs]) following the seasonal immunization against influenza. Patients who access the website (e.g., search for experiences with a certain vaccine) receive aggregated summary statistics of the ratings provided by other users, which are displayed in a pie chart. The graph indicates the relative frequency of VAEs reported within the network as well as their severity. In addition to viewing the summary statistics, users can also access “individual patient evaluations,” which display lists of individual narrative descriptions of the rated conditions. In the current study, we adopted the design of PLM (see Figure 1, which illustrates the materials used in this study, designed in the PLM style). On PLM, for example, of the 20 individuals who reported about the occurrence or nonoccurrence of adverse events after receiving the seasonal influenza vaccination, 6 individuals reported adverse events, resulting in the presence of VAEs in 30% of cases (www.patienslikeme.com, accessed 15 February 2012; search term: influenza vaccine). This sample, of course, is not representative but rather highly self-selected and biased. Thus, it is potentially skewed toward individuals with negative experiences with the vaccine or those with chronic conditions, which might have increased the a priori probabilities of the occurrence of adverse events.

body.p: In general, scientific evaluations of online patient networks have been quite positive and stress the benefits of such networks. Patients who use PLM more often also report deriving greater benefits. Specifically, self-reports about “how helpful” PLM was revealed that the site helped patients in starting or stopping medication or changing treatment dosages as well as understanding treatment side effects.6 A qualitative study shows that people interact based on the information provided, give advice to each other, and build networks.8 However, to the best of our knowledge, no study has quantitatively examined if and how information from online patient networks systematically affects decisions regarding pharmaceuticals.

The decision to protect oneself against a health threat can be predicted using a number of theories.9,10 Most models typically use the perception of the health risk (i.e., of the illness a vaccine protects against) to predict the uptake of protective behavior (vaccination). Perceptions about the risk given the preventive action are seldom reported.11 Vaccinations are a special case of preventive health behavior, as they involve the administration of pharmaceutical substances to a healthy organism. The substance may have undesired side effects, as do all medical treatments. Following the same logic of avoiding risks, higher perceived vaccination risk should lead to lower vaccination intentions. Thus, we focus on the perception of vaccination risk as well as whether reading statistical and/or narrative information as typically displayed in an online patient network affects vaccination risk perception and intention to vaccinate.

With this work, we relate directly to recent studies assessing the effect of narrative information on vaccination decisions, in which the existence of narratives about VAEs on websites increased the perceived risk of adverse events.4 Subsequent lab experiments showed that the more narratives that people read, the higher their perception of risk was, regardless of the information contained in simultaneously presented statistical information on the base rate of VAEs.5 The perceived risk of VAEs further mediated the relation between the narratives and declining vaccination intentions.5 This so-called narrative bias has also been demonstrated in other areas.12 As the underlying mechanisms are still unclear,13,14 researchers are reluctant to recommend the inclusion of narratives that indirectly mention either the risks or benefits of medical options in health communications (such as decision aids). Given that online patient networks can be considered self-organized, social media–like decision aids, it is especially important to assess their potential impact.

sec.title: Objectives and Hypotheses
sec.p: The goal of the current study was to explore how the information environment that is typically available in online patient networks—namely, a self-selected sample of patients whose experiences with pharmaceuticals are summarized in a pie chart and described in a narrative way—may influence people’s decisions regarding pharmaceuticals. As a domain, we used reports about VAEs. On the basis of the strong influence of narrative information and the specific set of information provided by PLM, we pose the following hypotheses.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: We expect that a higher relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs will increase perceived risk of vaccinating.

Hypothesis 2: We expect that the manner in which side effect data are displayed will moderate the effect of the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs: Perceived risk should be more strongly related to variations in the relative frequency of VAEs when users also read narrative information as compared with users who have access only to statistical summary information (narrative bias).

Hypothesis 3: We assess if a higher relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs decreases the intention to get vaccinated. If so, this effect should be mediated by increased risk perception, as has been shown previously.5

sec.p: When individuals receive information about a source’s lack of reliability and trustworthiness, the impact of the source’s information is reduced immediately by this discounting cue.15 Thus, awareness that the sample of individuals delivering the information is potentially biased should decrease trust in the online patient network as a source of reliable health information. Consequently, we test the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 4a: When users are made aware of potential sampling biases before encoding information, reports of VAEs should be discounted; in turn, variations in the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs should have a lesser or even no effect on risk perceptions and vaccination intentions.16

Hypothesis 4b: As a second discounting cue, we included one condition in which nearly all narratives report the occurrence of VAEs (i.e., 85%). This unreasonably high proportion might also make individuals aware of the highly skewed sample, thus undermining the trustworthiness of the source. We expect that this will reduce the effect of the narratives on risk perceptions and vaccination intentions.

sec.p: We also explored the role of numeracy, that is, the ability to use and understand numbers.17 Previous research has shown that people with low numeracy make suboptimal health decisions and are affected more by biased narrative information than individuals with high numeracy.18 We therefore expect the following:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 5: Individuals with low numeracy will rely more strongly on narrative as compared with statistical information.

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: Participants received detailed information about a fictitious disease: Dysomerie was described as highly infectious, transmittable via droplets, and associated with severe symptoms (fever, emesis, meningitis) and long-term risks (palsy). The participants learned that the German Standing Committee on Vaccination (STIKO) recommends vaccination against the illness. An icon array19 illustrated the base rate of VAEs (20%). Thereafter, participants received information about a fictitious online patient network with a disclaimer either indicating the presence of sampling bias or stressing the importance and value of the single contributions (see below). Participants then read the information presented in the social network. Depending on the condition, the social network presented either narrative reports about postvaccination experiences (with varying percentages of cases reporting VAEs), summary statistics of the same information, or both, in which case the statistical summary preceded the corresponding narratives. After encoding the information, the dependent variables (risk perception, vaccination intention), manipulation checks, descriptive variables, and numeracy were collected.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Participants were recruited via mailing lists and the Internet (Twitter, Facebook, websites related to childhood topics). As an incentive, we raffled off five 25€ (~US $34.50) gift certificates for a large Internet store. In total, 1543 individuals clicked on the link to the study. Of the 953 participants who proceeded to the first page of the survey, 605 completed the study; 147 indicated that they had previously participated in a similar study and were therefore excluded from the sample. Participants were randomly assigned to a 3 (relative frequency of adverse events in 1, 7, or 17 of 20 cases; equaling 5%, 35%, and 85%, respectively) × 3 (type of information: narratives, summary statistics, or both) × 2 (bias awareness v. control disclaimer) between-subjects design.

The information was provided within a simulated social network similar in style to the website www.patientslikeme.com (cf. Figure 1). As in the disclaimer of PLM, the simulated site included the statement that the network provides “access to side effect surveys and treatment evaluations to report your experiences with medications and other treatments you use, including your experiences with adverse events.”20

sec.title: Disclaimer
sec.p: Disclaimers were used to manipulate bias awareness. The bias-awareness disclaimer informed participants that the information provided by the social network may be biased and nonrepresentative due to patient self-selection: “In contrast to results from clinical studies, the patient reports published here are not representative of the experiences of all people who have received the respective medical product. The authors independently registered at the Patientenportal.de and voluntarily reported their experiences without being asked to do so. Therefore, it is possible that a self-selection is present. The published reports represent only the authors’ individual perceptions.” The control disclaimer was copied from PLM and stressed the importance of individual contributions to the network20: “While there is much information learned from clinical trials, they do not fully reflect the way a medical product is used in real life. By completing these reports, you can help improve the outcomes and safety of patients by contributing real world safety data to drug manufacturers and regulators.” In both conditions, participants also read that the network does not provide medical advice.

sec.title: Relative frequency of VAE
sec.p: To assess the impact of the information provided in the social network, we systematically varied the relative frequency of patients in the social network who had experienced VAEs such that it decreased and increased the initially stated base rate (i.e., 20%) by 15% (i.e., 5% and 35%, respectively) and exceeded it remarkably (85%). Thus, depending on condition, 5%, 35%, or 85% of patients reported mild VAEs (e.g., insomnia, fever, rash, emesis; the VAEs used were pretested and ranged between 1.97 and 2.77 on a 1–7 severity scale; unpublished data*), whereas the remaining patients reported unproblematic vaccination experiences.

sec.title: Type of information
sec.p: In the narratives condition, the vaccination experiences of the patients within the social network were displayed as single narratives, with 4 narratives on 1 of 5 pages; the 5 pages were displayed in random order. Two sets of 5 pages each were created to allow for counterbalancing the sex of patients reporting VAEs. The narratives, both those describing VAEs and those reporting an absence of VAEs, were of equal length (VAE, mean = 18 words; no VAE, mean = 18.5 words). In the narratives condition, 1, 7, or 17 narratives reported VAEs (resulting in relative frequencies of 5%, 35%, and 85%, respectively). In the summary statistics condition, experiences were displayed in a pie chart with 5%, 35%, or 85% colored in orange, indicating the occurrence of mild VAEs; the cases without VAEs were displayed in green. In the third condition, participants first viewed the summary pie chart with 5%, 35%, or 85% VAEs before reading the narratives, which reflected the distribution displayed in the pie chart. This sequence was not counterbalanced, as we aimed to approximate the design and sequence of information provided by PLM.

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: Risk was assessed by means of a scroll bar (“How risky do you judge the vaccination against Dysomerie to be?” ranging from 0 = not at all risky to 100 = very risky; numeric anchors were not visible to participants). Perceived probability was assessed by asking for the numeric percentage of VAEs following vaccinations against Dysomerie. The severity of potential VAEs was rated on a 7-point scale (1 = not severe; 7 = very severe). Participants’ intentions to get vaccinated against Dysomerie if they had the chance to do so in the upcoming week were rated on a 7-point scale (1 = definitely not vaccinate; 7 = definitely vaccinate).

sec.title: Manipulation checks and descriptive variables
sec.p: To assess whether the information contained in the disclaimer increased participants’ awareness of the skewed sample of contributions within the social network, we asked participants which source they trusted more when reading about pharmaceuticals’ risks (1 = clinical trials; 7 = personal reports such as those in the social network). Participants also judged how representative they considered the reports published in the social network to be (1 = not at all representative, they provide a biased picture; 7 = representative, they correspond to reality). As additional manipulation checks, we asked participants to recall the initially stated base rate of VAEs as well as the information provided in the social network (narrative, statistical, or both, depending on condition).

Personal e-health routines were assessed with importance ratings (1 = unimportant; 5 = important) of several sources (health professionals, reference books; books; Internet; courses and lectures; family, friends, and colleagues; pharmacies; newspapers and magazines; and TV/radio3); in addition, we asked participants how often they use the Internet to search for health information. We also assessed membership at online patient networks as well as participants’ general attitudes toward vaccination (1 = totally against vaccination; 7 = totally in favor of vaccination).

Numeracy was assessed via the 8-item subjective numeracy scale, which uses self-report items (e.g., “How good are you at working with percentages?” “How good are you at figuring out how much a shirt will cost if it is 25% off?” with 1 expressing the low numeracy response and 6 expressing the high numeracy response) to assess an individual’s ability to understand and use numbers.17,18,21,22 Cronbach’s α was 0.82.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The sample comprises 458 participants (85.6% female; mean [SD] age 31.71 [8.91], 70% with German Abitur or higher education). Of the participants, 4.5% (n = 20) indicated that they were members of an online patient network; 43%, 38%, and 19% use the Internet to search for health information up to once a year, once a month, or on a weekly or daily basis, respectively. The Internet was rated as the fourth most important source overall (mean [SD] 3.62 [1.02]; 95% confidence interval [CI], 3.52–3.72), less important than medical personnel (4.33 [0.88]; 4.25–4.41), medical books or brochures (3.93 [1.01]; 3.83–4.02), and pharmacies (3.78 [1.05]; 3.68–3.87). All other sources were rated as less important than the Internet (e.g., family and friends, etc.). The mean (SD) time required to complete the study was 9.94 (3.49) minutes. Participants had a mean (SD) numeracy of 4.18 (0.95) and were generally more in favor of vaccination than against it (5.57 [1.51]).

sec.title: Manipulation checks
sec.p: Following the dependent measures, we assessed the recalled base rate of VAEs that was initially presented to the participants (before the social network information was provided). The majority of participants correctly recalled the base rate (mode = 20; n = 349). However, the manipulations within the social network also affected the recalled base rate: The higher the probability of VAEs implied by the reports in the social network, the higher the recalled base rate was (mean [SD] 17.65 [5.81] for the 5% condition, 19.4 [6.9] for 35%, and 25.1 [11.36] for 85%), F(2, 455) = 20.34, P < 0.001.

When asked for the information provided within the social network setting, participants indicated that they remembered a mean (SD) number of 1.43 (1.8) narratives reporting adverse events (correct answer = 1) in the 5% condition, 7.88 (7.49; correct = 7) in the 35% condition, and 17.04 (10.29; correct = 17) in the 85% condition, F(2, 311) = 115.5, P < 0.001. Likewise, the recalled statistical information provided by the patient network differed as an effect of the displayed probability, with a mean (SD) of 8.91 (7.79), 25.43 (13.59), and 49.50 (28.92) in the 5%, 35%, and 85% conditions, respectively, F(2, 291) = 112.67, P < 0.001. Especially in the 85% condition, participants appeared to have difficulties remembering the correct summary statistics. A comparison of the absolute differences between the stated and recalled number of narratives and summary statistics (in the group that received both) shows that deviations were indeed much larger in the summary statistics group, as suggested by the previous findings, F(1, 147) = 138.43, P < 0.001.

It is possible that the disclaimer requires a high educational level, as it includes concepts such as clinical studies and self-selection. We therefore controlled for education level (Abitur and higher, n = 317 v. below Abitur, n = 141) in the following analyses: Participants who received the bias-awareness disclaimer perceived patient self-reports as less trustworthy (mean [SD] 2.66 [1.49] v. 3.32 [1.72]; F(1, 454) = 14.81, P < 0.001) and judged the information provided in the social network to be less representative (2.89 [1.41] v. 3.32 [1.56]; F(1, 454) = 8.11, P = 0.01) than participants who received the control disclaimer. Education had a main effect on both variables: Highly educated participants perceived patient self-reports as generally less trustworthy, F(1, 454) = 17.47, P < 0.001, and judged the information provided in the social network to be less representative, F(1, 454) = 36.23, P < 0.001. Education did not interact with the effect of the bias-awareness disclaimer (Fs < 1.07).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: In the following, we use regression analyses to test the hypotheses. To assess the effect of information type, we created 2 dummy variables with the summary statistics as the reference group. In the following, we will refer to the 2 variables as “narrative information” (= 1, rest = 0) and “summary statistics plus narratives” (= 1, rest = 0). For all regression analyses, we centered predictors and created interaction terms by multiplying the respective predictors.23

sec.title: Risk perception
sec.p: In a regression analysis, the following variables predicted the perceived risk of VAEs: relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs, information types used to communicate these frequencies, bias-awareness disclaimer, interactions between the relative frequency of the cases and information types, and the interaction between relative frequency and the disclaimer (see Table 1; R2 = 0.19). The higher the relative frequency of cases that reported VAEs, the higher the perceived risk of VAEs was (hypothesis 1); this relation was weakest when cases were displayed as a summary statistic (r between risk and relative frequency = 0.27, P < 0.001), stronger when vaccination experiences were communicated by narratives (r = 0.44, P < 0.001), and strongest when both types of information were provided (r = 0.48, P < 0.001). This pattern of results confirms hypothesis 2 and is mirrored by the interaction terms of the types of information and relative frequency (see Figure 2). Participants who received the bias-awareness disclaimer were less sensitive to variations in the relative frequency of cases that reported VAEs, as indicated by the disclaimer × relative frequency interaction (hypothesis 4a): In the presence of a bias-awareness disclaimer, perceived risk correlated with relative frequency at r = 0.34, P < 0.001; in the presence of a control disclaimer, the correlation was r = 0.46, P < 0.001 (Fisher’s z = −1.52, P = 0.06).

sec.title: Numeracy
sec.p: To assess whether the ability to understand and use numbers affected risk judgments, we included numeracy in the regression analyses reported above in addition to the following interactions: the interaction with the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs to assess whether highly numerate participants’ risk judgments reflected the variations in relative frequency differently than those of less-numerate participants, as well as 3-way interactions with the different types of information to assess whether highly numerate participants’ risk judgments were affected more strongly by the summary statistics than those of less-numerate participants.

The pattern reported above remained stable. The effect of the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs on perceived risk was greater for participants with high numeracy (interaction β = 0.09, P < 0.05; r = 0.48, P < 0.001 for high numeracy and r = 0.30, P < 0.001 for low numeracy; Fisher’s z = −2.26, P = 0.01), irrespective of information type (no significant 3-way interactions, which yields no support for hypothesis 5; Ps > 0.25). The results remained the same when controlling for level of education, which can be seen as a proxy for general literacy.

sec.title: Probability change
sec.p: We assessed both the perceived probability and the recalled initial base rate of VAEs. The difference between the 2 variables represents the estimated effect of the patient network information on perceived risk. We subjected this difference score to the same regression model reported above (see Table 1). The relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs was related to changes in the perceived probability; more cases led to higher probability judgments. Participants who received the bias-awareness disclaimer showed a smaller effect of the patient network information—their perception of probability was influenced less by the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs (correlation between probability change and relative frequency for participants with bias disclaimer: r = 0.27, P < 0.001; control disclaimer: r = 0.39, P < 0.001). All other predictors did not influence changes in the recalled probability of VAEs.

sec.title: Intention to get vaccinated
sec.p: The mean intention varied around the scale’s midpoint (mean [SD] 3.9 [1.89]; see Figure 3) and followed the same pattern as risk perception (R2 = 0.083). This provides support for hypothesis 3 (see Table 1). The higher the relative frequency of cases that reported VAEs, the lower the intention to get vaccinated was. This relation was weakest when cases were displayed as a summary statistic (r between intention and relative frequency = −0.14, ns), stronger when vaccination experiences were communicated in narratives (r = −0.254, P < 0.001), and strongest when both types of information were provided (r = −0.351, P < 0.001). In addition, in the presence of a bias-awareness disclaimer, vaccination intentions correlated with relative frequency at r = −0.17 (ns); in the presence of a control disclaimer, the correlation was r = −0.33, P < 0.001 (see Figure 3). Thus, vaccination intentions were influenced to a lesser extent by the risk information provided in the patient network when a bias-awareness disclaimer was present.

caption.p: Intention to vaccinate as a function of the relative frequency of cases reporting vaccine adverse events (VAEs) and disclaimer type.

sec.title: Mediation analysis
sec.p: In a mediation analysis, we assessed whether the effect of patient information on the occurrence of VAEs on vaccination intentions was mediated by risk perception (hypothesis 35). We calculated 2 models (displayed in Figure 4). In model 1, the perceived risk fully mediated the relation between information about VAEs and intention (Sobel test z = 4.764, P < 0.001). In model 2, we explored the effects of risk information on 2 constituents of risk: the perceived probability and expected severity of VAEs.24 A great number of cases reporting VAEs resulted in an especially large increase in the recalled probability of VAEs as well as the expected severity of adverse events. Perceived risk was strongly predicted by the perceived severity of adverse events.

caption.p: Mediation models testing hypothesis 2. VAE, vaccine adverse event. M indicates a significant mediation effect. *P < 0.05.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The goal of this contribution was to explore the effect of anecdotal information regarding adverse events. Such information is readily available through patient social networks. We assessed whether patient experiences summarized in narratives and statistics have the potential to influence vaccine decisions by influencing risk perceptions. The data confirmed our first hypothesis that a higher relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs increases perceived vaccination risk. The type of information moderated the contents’ impact: Summary statistics had the smallest impact, whereas narrative information was more influential, and the presence of both types of information had the greatest impact on risk perception (hypothesis 2). The relative number of cases reporting VAEs also decreased intentions to get vaccinated. As expected, this relation was mediated by increased risk perception (hypothesis 3).

Although all participants received the same initial information about the base rate of adverse events, perceived risk varied according to the personal reports provided by other people in the patient network. The results show that summary statistics influence risk judgments. However, narrative information was more influential than statistical information and most influential when combined with summary statistics. It is possible that receiving both the narratives and summary statistics leads to enhanced encoding and easier recall of the relative number of VAEs. However, the data suggest that this was not the case, as participants in the condition with both summary statistics and narratives did not recall the number of narratives more accurately than those who viewed only the narratives without the statistical summary (F < 1). Furthermore, the time elapsed between encoding the initial statistics and the assessment of the dependent variables was greatest in the combined condition, which could impede the correct recall of the initial base rate information (20% VAE). However, participants in this condition did not show poorer recall of the initial statistics, F < 1. Thus, it appears that, overall, the narrative information was encoded better than the statistical information, as is already apparent in the manipulation check data.

The reported results add to the growing body of evidence on the narrative bias5,13,14 (i.e., that narrative information can bias risk judgments even when base rate information is also presented). To illustrate the impact of narrative information, we calculated the relative frequency of adverse events necessary to shift the intention from “rather vaccinate” (>4) to “rather not vaccinate” (<4). When the relative frequency was communicated in the form of statistical information, 35.7% of the reported sample must have experienced adverse events for participants to shift their intentions from vaccinating to not vaccinating. When communicated in the form of narratives, the relative frequency need only be 25.5% for participants to change their intentions (i.e., roughly 10% fewer cases than when using statistical information). Previous research suggests that narratives that are formulated in a more emotional way (than the ones used in this study) are likely to be even more influential.5 Thus, the effect size estimates of the relative frequency of narratives may be considered rather conservative. Furthermore, the mediation analysis indicated that perceived severity influences risk perceptions to an even greater extent than the perceived probability of adverse events. Therefore, narratives presenting cases with high severity are likely to be more influential than the narratives reporting mild VAEs used in the current study.

The relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs was varied systematically such that it decreased and increased the stated initial probability (i.e., 20%) by 15% (i.e., 5% and 35%) and exceeded it remarkably (85%). The effect of narratives was not symmetric: In the 5% condition, the mean (SD) deviation of the probability judgment from the recalled initial probability was −1.42 (11.64), whereas it was 4.43 (12.67) in the 35% condition. Thus, even though the narratives deviated equally from the initial probability in terms of relative frequency, perceived risk did not decrease in the 5% condition as much as it increased in the 35% condition. This is in line with findings that suggest that individuals trust information stating the presence of risk more than they trust information stating an absence of risk.25–27 On the basis of this finding, future studies should assess whether patient networks are more likely to increase rather than decrease risk perceptions.

We included the 85% condition to assess whether participants perceive exceptionally high deviations from the initial base rate statistics to be invalid and discount them as a result (hypothesis 4b). The reported results show that perceived risk increased from the 35% to the 85% condition, thus contradicting the idea that the exceptionally frequent reports were discounted. In line with this finding, there was also no relation between trusting narratives v. clinical trials and the relative frequency of cases reporting adverse events (r = 0.06, P = 0.21). Thus, even though the 85% condition strongly exceeded the initial probability of VAEs, participants took the information seriously and integrated it into their judgments.

Contrary to hypothesis 5 and previous findings,18 risk perceptions of individuals with low numeracy were not affected more strongly by the narrative information than were those of highly numerate individuals. Rather, in this study, highly numerate individuals were generally more sensitive to the provided information independent of its format. As the results remained the same when we controlled for education level (as a proxy for general literacy), we assume that the effect is not the result of highly numerate individuals’ higher general literacy. Even though recent findings indicate that highly numerate individuals can make better use of provided health information,17 the results of the present study raise the question whether higher numeracy is always advantageous. The provided patient network information (5%, 35%, 85%) deviated from the initially stated 20% VAE and, therefore, biased the judgments of highly numerate individuals more strongly than of those of less-numerate individuals. One potential speculative explanation might be that highly numerate individuals processed the information without assessing its validity, perhaps because they felt more ease in processing the information than individuals with low numeracy. Future research should test the hypothesis whether the ease (or fluency28) with which information is processed (due to high or low numeracy) has an influence on the degree to which individuals trust the information. A feeling of disfluency (due to low numeracy) may induce a more critical mind-set,29 thus resulting in a lesser influence of unreliable information.

Half of the participants received a bias-awareness disclaimer informing them about potential biases in the sample delivering the information. We expected that such a disclaimer would reduce or eliminate the effect of the information provided in the patient network (hypothesis 4a). Analyses showed that individuals who received the bias-awareness disclaimer were less sensitive to variations in the relative frequency of cases reporting VAEs and that their vaccination intentions were influenced less by the risk information provided in the patient network. However, the effect was rather weak, despite the fact that individuals who read the bias-awareness disclaimer had less trust in the patient reports and considered the information to be less representative than participants who read the control disclaimer. It seems that participants did not completely discount the information provided by the network but instead attributed it less weight in their judgments. Future research should assess whether— despite the partial discounting of the information at the time of the judgment—the encoded information gains more weight over time, as suggested by research on the sleeper effect.15 This will help assess the potential (long-term) benefits of disclaimers.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: A number of possible limitations to the results should be noted. First, we employed a hypothetical scenario and collected self-report data with regard to vaccination intentions. Thus, responses were without consequences for the participants and might therefore have limited external validity. Furthermore, individual perceptions of the illness were not assessed (such as perceived severity or personal susceptibility). According to several theories of protective health behavior,9,10 these constructs also affect the intention for protective behavior. As a consequence, the results regarding the vaccination intention should be viewed cautiously. Future research should strive to move to the realm of real-life decisions, assess the full set of variables relevant to predict behavior, and follow up on actual behavior. If this is unfeasible due to financial or ethical constraints, settings could be created in such a way that biased answers are somehow costly for participants (e.g., by reducing the chances of monetary rewards in proportion to the reported bias), thereby creating a more robust test of the observed effects.30

Second, 2 apparent core properties of social networks were missing from the simulated patient network in our study’s design: actual membership and interactivity.31 Known and trusted sources of information are more likely to affect attitudes and behavior,32 and membership appears to be a prerequisite for developing knowledge of and trust in other members of a network. This limitation suggests that the effect sizes in this study might be conservative due to lacking membership and subsequently low trust. However, much of the information on PLM is also available for nonmembers and certainly has the advantage of being authored by “people like me” as opposed to an official source. “People like me” may be seen as credible, trustworthy, and lacking an additional agenda.33,34 Although active participation is essential for developing virtual relationships and experiencing social support,35 simply reading others’ reports led to an equally high reception of information in online patient support groups.36

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: One positive aspect of patient networks that has not yet been discussed may be that narratives reporting the absence of adverse events are published online, which, to date, occurs only occasionally.37 Narratives about the absence of adverse events will allow users who search for narrative information (e.g., parents who already perceive high vaccination risks38) to receive a more balanced picture of what might occur following vaccination.

As the number of individuals who search for health information in interactive online environments is increasing, patient networks represent an important environment that deserves more scientific attention. The present research suggests that patient networks may be influential in terms of medication decisions, as they deliver narrative and statistical information about risk. Future research should assess whether changes in perceptions of risk due to patient network information may be the driver for reported changes in dosage, medications, or doctors.6–8 Furthermore, disclaimers referring to potential biases in the samples underlying the shared data seem useful in real patient networks, especially because humans are not naturally sensitive to sampling biases.39,40
